sn45.27:4.2: “A pot without a stand is easy to overturn, but if it has a stand it’s hard to overturn.
sn45.27:4.3: In the same way, a mind without a stand is easy to overturn, but if it has a stand it’s hard to overturn.
sn45.27:4.4: And what’s the stand for the mind?
sn45.27:4.5: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
sn45.27:4.6: right view, right motivation, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right samādhi.
sn45.27:4.8: This is the stand for the mind.
sn45.27:4.9: A pot without a stand is easy to overturn, but if it has a stand it’s hard to overturn.
sn45.27:4.10: In the same way, a mind without a stand is easy to overturn, but if it has a stand it’s hard to overturn.”
